Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: Senior OpenAI leaders, including Mr. Sutskever, who is deeply concerned that A.I. could one day destroy humanity, later discussed whether Ms. Toner should be removed, a person involved in the conversations said.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: a person involved in the conversations

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: But shortly after those discussions, Mr. Sutskever did the unexpected: He sided with board members to oust Mr. Altman, according to two people familiar with the board’s deliberations.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: two people familiar with the board’s deliberations

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: That scientist and other researchers went to the board to try to push Mr. Altman out. After they failed, they gave up and departed, according to three people familiar with the attempt to push Mr. Altman out.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: three people familiar with the attempt to push Mr. Altman out

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: After vetting four candidates for one position, the remaining directors couldn’t agree on who should fill it, said the two people familiar with the board’s deliberations.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: the two people familiar with the board’s deliberations

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: Hours after Mr. Altman was ousted, OpenAI executives confronted the remaining board members during a video call, according to three people who were on the call.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: three people who were on the call

Anonymous Sources.Sourced Statement: On Sunday, Mr. Sutskever was urged at OpenAI’s office to reverse course by Mr. Brockman’s wife, Anna, according to two people familiar with the exchange.
Anonymous Sources.Source Justification: two people familiar with the exchange

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: The decision stunned OpenAI’s employees and exposed board members to tough questions about their qualifications to manage such a high-profile company.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: The decision stunned OpenAI’s employees and exposed board members to tough questions about their qualifications to manage such a high-profile company.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Nearly all of OpenAI’s 800 employees had threatened to follow Mr. Altman to Microsoft, which asked him to lead an A.I. lab with Greg Brockman, who quit his roles as OpenAI’s president and board chairman in solidarity with Mr. Altman.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Nearly all of OpenAI’s 800 employees had threatened to follow Mr. Altman to Microsoft, which asked him to lead an A.I. lab with Greg Brockman, who quit his roles as OpenAI’s president and board chairman in solidarity with Mr. Altman.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Mr. Altman complained that the research paper seemed to criticize OpenAI’s efforts to keep its A.I. technologies safe while praising the approach taken by Anthropic, a company that has become OpenAI’s biggest rival, according to an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times.
Document Sources.Source Justification: an email that Mr. Altman wrote to colleagues and that was viewed by The New York Times

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: The news that he was being pushed out came in a videoconference on Friday afternoon, when Mr. Sutskever, who had worked closely with Mr. Altman at OpenAI for eight years, read him a statement.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: Those tensions seemingly came to an end late Tuesday when Mr. Altman was reinstated as chief executive. Mr. Sutskever and others critical of Mr. Altman were jettisoned from the board, whose members now include Bret Taylor, an early Facebook officer and former co-chief executive of Salesforce, and Larry Summers, the former Treasury Department secretary. The only holdover is Adam D’Angelo, chief executive of the question-and-answer site, Quora.
